importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Naroditsky won the under-12 World Youth Chess Championship in November 2007, establishing himself as a top young talent.
Naroditsky graduated from Stanford University with a bachelor’s degree in history in 2019.
The New York Times hired Naroditsky as a chess columnist in 2022, marking a significant milestone in his media and educational outreach.
The 2025 US Chess Championship began with a moment of silence in honor of Naroditsky, indicating his lasting impact on the chess community.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2007 to 2019 covers Naroditsky’s rise from youth champion to collegiate graduate and public chess educator, showcasing a sustained career trajectory in chess excellence and education.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster, died at age 29.
He earned the title of grandmaster before high school graduation and won multiple national youth championships.
He became a prominent chess commentator, educator, and online presence with nearly half a million YouTube subscribers and 340,000 Twitch followers.
Naroditsky authored chess manuals at age 14 and contributed to Chess Life magazine and the New York Times as a columnist.
The Charlotte Chess Center, where he served as head coach, and the International Chess Federation both publicly mourned his death.
A moment of silence was observed at the 2025 US Chess Championship in St. Louis in his honor.
The Saint Louis Chess Club described him as a 'beloved pillar of the chess community' whose passion and teaching inspired players globally.
His family requested privacy and urged the public to remember him for his love of chess and the joy he brought to others.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, an American chess grandmaster born in the San Francisco Bay Area, died at the age of 29. A prodigy who earned the grandmaster title before high school and won multiple youth championships, Naroditsky became a globally recognized figure through his accessible teaching, livestreamed games, and online platforms, including YouTube and Twitch. He contributed to major publications like Chess Life and the New York Times, and served as head coach at the Charlotte Chess Center. The International Chess Federation and the Saint Louis Chess Club praised his contributions, and the 2025 US Chess Championship began with a moment of silence in his honor. His legacy lives on through his influence on chess education and community engagement worldwide.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
